item.title: Lindsey add a quote by William Styron
item.description: "The good writing of any age has always been the product of someone's neurosis, and we'd have a mighty dull literature if all the writers that came along were a bunch of happy chuckleheads." -- William Styron

item.title: Lindsey add a quote by Milan Kundera
item.description: "People are always shouting they want to create a better future. It's not true. The future is an apathetic void of no interest to anyone. The past is full of life, eager to irritate us, provoke and insult us, tempt us to destroy or repaint it. The only reason people want to be masters of the future is to change the past." -- Milan Kundera

item.title: Lindsey add a quote by Milan Kundera
item.description: "for there is nothing heavier than compassion. Not even one's own pain weighs so heavy as the pain one feels with someone, for someone, a pain intensified by the imagination and prolonged by a hundred echoes." -- Milan Kundera

item.title: Lindsey add a quote by Margaret Atwood
item.description: "If you knew what was going to happen, if you knew everything that was going to happen next—if you knew in advance the consequences of your own actions—you'd be doomed. You'd be ruined as God. You'd be a stone. You'd never eat or drink or laugh or get out of bed in the morning. You'd never love anyone, ever again. You'd never dare to." -- Margaret Atwood

item.title: Lindsey add a quote by Margaret Atwood
item.description: "I would like to be the air that inhabits you for a moment only. I would like to be that unnoticed and that necessary." -- Margaret Atwood

item.title: Lindsey add a quote by Margaret Atwood
item.description: "The only way you can write the truth is to assume that what you set down will never be read. Not by any other person, and not even by yourself at some later date. Otherwise you begin excusing yourself. You must see the writing as emerging like a long scroll of ink from the index finger of your right hand; you must see your left hand erasing it." -- Margaret Atwood

item.title: Lindsey add a quote by Elie Wiesel
item.description: "The opposite of love is not hate, it's indifference. The opposite of art is not ugliness, it's indifference. The opposite of faith is not heresy, it's indifference. And the opposite of life is not death, it's indifference." -- Elie Wiesel

item.title: Lindsey add a quote by Oscar Wilde
item.description: "I am so clever that sometimes I don't understand a single word of what I am saying." -- Oscar Wilde

item.title: Lindsey add a quote by Virginia Woolf
item.description: "I have lost friends, some by death...others by sheer inability to cross the street." -- Virginia Woolf

item.title: Lindsey add a quote by Virginia Woolf
item.description: "The history of men's opposition to women's emancipation is more interesting perhaps than the story of that emancipation itself." -- Virginia Woolf

item.title: Lindsey add a quote by Anais Nin
item.description: "We write to taste life twice, in the moment and in retrospect." -- Anais Nin

item.title: Lindsey add a quote by Jonathan Safran Foer
item.description: "I love you also means I love you more than anyone loves you, or has loved you, or will love you, and also, I love you in a way that no one loves you, or has loved you, or will love you, and also, I love you in a way that I love no one else, and never have loved anyone else, and never will love anyone else." -- Jonathan Safran Foer

item.title: Lindsey add a quote by Edna St. Vincent Millay
item.description: "It's not true that life is one damn thing after another; it's one damn thing over and over." -- Edna St. Vincent Millay

item.title: Lindsey add a quote by Alice Munro
item.description: "There is a limit to the amount of misery and disarray you will put up with, for love, just as there is a limit to the amount of mess you can stand around a house. You can't know the limit beforehand, but you will know when you've reached it. I believe this." -- Alice Munro

item.title: Lindsey add a quote by Simone Weil
item.description: "A beautiful woman looking at her image in the mirror may very well believe the image is herself. An ugly woman knows it is not." -- Simone Weil
